       Executive Summary
This evaluation aims to assess the program’s implementation and ensure the achievement of the program’s outcomes. Thus, the evaluation provides insights into the program’s impact on the resulting outcomes of the implemented approach and mitigation measures. The evaluation covers the program's entire implementation period. Specifically, AltCity Impact/Bloom’s improvement of best practices following the mid-program evaluation, completed on January 31, 2022. 
Additionally, the evaluation assesses the Theory of Change and if the fundamental assumptions supporting it are still valid in light of the changing circumstances. 
This evaluation covers the Youth Entrepreneurship & Employability Accelerators Program (YEEAP), which has three main outcomes:  
An effective community of practice (Training Partners and MSMEs) with improved capacities supports MSMEs to operate in complex economic environments
Capable MSMEs operate successfully in complex economic environments
AltCity Impact / Bloom.org with strengthened organizational abilities to deliver sustained and growing economic impact for MSMEs in complex environments
Overall, the AltCity Impact/Bloom successfully met its targets in all the outcomes despite the challenging times and crises the country has been going through in the past two years.
Our evaluation looked at not only the ToC, methodology, and indicators but also the overall program. It evaluated it at a programmatic and operational level to provide findings and recommendations for future programming.
A dedicated section is provided at the end with the recommendations for RDPP and AltCity Impact/Bloom to consider and build on for even more effective, efficient, impactful, and sustainable programming in the future.

Methodology  
Building on previous similar projects and per the requirements, the evaluators adopted a participatory mixed methods approach to producing the required deliverables. This includes a desk review and qualitative and quantitative data collection.  We collected input from all stakeholders and analyzed them to generate the necessary findings and recommendations.
The evaluation was conducted over four main stages: 


II.1 Phase One – Desk Review

In this phase, the team of researchers reviewed the relevant project documents including:
Initial TOR (to extract the intended goals from the program)
Project’s Vision and Mission
Project’s Theory of Change 
Project proposals and narrative reports (prepared during the duration of the project)
Project’s Logical Framework
Project’s MEAL Plan and PITT Sheet
Job Desegregation data
The Quarterly Information Note (Start of the Project - Cut off September 30, 2022)
AC_PWorg YEEA Annual Report 3 (2022-08-20 - shared) - Copy for RPS
Contact lists for the evaluation

Four sets of tools were developed and presented in the following sections to be addressed to 1) enterprises, 2) training partners, 3) mentors, and 4) the team members.

II.2 Phase Two - Data Collection 
The team, the network members’ input, and the beneficiaries’ were collected via a questionnaire to extract quantifiable indices to measure relevance, effectiveness, and efficiency levels. 
The data collection method includes two steps: 1. digitization of the questionnaire and the dissemination of the questionnaire link via emails; 2. researchers collected the responses while maintaining the respondents’ anonymity and confidentiality.

Sampling strategy: Given that the number of enterprises, training partners, mentors, and team members was attainable, four surveys were distributed to all members to solicit their opinion via the questionnaire. To boost the response rate from the MSMEs and to attain unbiased input. To boost the MSMEs' response rate and to validate the number of jobs created, the RPS team contacted, surveyed, and interviewed the MSMEs via several ways (rounds). Accordingly, 39 MSMEs filled out the survey (on which we built the statistical figures) and 2 joined the discussions, hence a total of 42 MSMEs participated in this evaluation, whereas 7 MSMEs did not (did not fill the survey, nor respond to any of the 3 follow emails, nor answered any of the phone calls, nor participate in the FGD or interviews). Based on the results of the surveys, follow-up interviews were held with each group to explain further the findings.

II.3 Phase Three - Data Cleaning, Findings, and Analysis
Qualitative
The RPS Team stored all notes from the interviews on a secured drive. In addition, the notes were reviewed and validated to ensure the quality and accuracy of the information.
The team used a content analysis approach and was able to delve into the details and triangulate the results of the survey and desk review.

Quantitative
The team provided data from the surveys into standard Microsoft Excel format. Then the team did a round of data cleansing and validation to ensure that the data collected was valid and valuable.
Accordingly, the team generated the statistical findings and relevant artifacts such as pivots, tables, cross tabs, and charts to present the results appropriately.
II.4 Phase Four Final Report
The findings, analysis, and recommendations resulted from the triangulation of the findings collected via the literature review, and the qualitative and quantitative data. Although some of the interviews were administered in Arabic, this final evaluation report is entirely in English. The information is organized as followed:
Executive summary     
Methodology
The Evaluation
Conclusions and recommendations  
Appendices
The Evaluation
This assessment is aligned with the OECD evaluation criteria of: relevance, effectiveness, efficiency, impact, sustainability, and coherence. In the end, the evaluators proceed with the evaluation in that order and conclude it with the lessons learned to pave the way for future planning.
III.1 About the MSMEs 
A substantial positive impact was notable on all the participating MSMEs in the Lebanese Growth Accelerator (LGA) implemented by Bloom (an affiliate of AltCity). The MSMEs came from different sectors and backgrounds such as: agro-food, manufacturing, crafts, design, technology, and other sectors. The MSME owners’ age distribution are mainly in their youth or prime age (47% between 18 and 31 years old, 32% between 32 and 45 years old, and the rest above 45 years old). Additionally, there is gender inclusion among the founders of the MSMEs participating in the project, with 49% males and 51% females. 

The MSMEs joined the LGA program via different outreach channels, mainly via the call for MSMEs issued by the Bloom team. Around 47% of the participants in this evaluation indicated joining the program through applying. The other three channels are; 1. a contact person who introduced them to the Bloom team (21%), 2. one of the implementing partners (16%), and 3. some were contacted by the Bloom team (16%).

III.2 Relevance 
There is an agreement among the Bloom team members, the mentors, and the participants (MSMEs) that the LGA project aligns with Bloom’s vision and mission from one side and is relevant to the needs of the MSMEs from another. The details relevant to the MSMEs’ perceptions are reported under the decent jobs criteria section. This evaluation shows that the LGA project aligns with Bloom’s vision and mission over three main fronts. First, the LGA project succeeded in enrolling, training, and supporting 49 MSMEs in the program. Second, the LGA project uses the online modality to increase the opportunities for discussion, community exchange, and support. Third, this program succeeded in capacitating the MSMEs, each in the area of their need. This helped them unveil new income opportunities and create at least 564 short-term, part-time, and full-time jobs for refugees and marginalized communities. In total, 514 positions were filled by Lebanese (males and females) and 50 positions by refugees (males and females). The modality of the employment varied from short-term, to part-time, to full-time, depending on the capacity of the MSMEs to retain the new labor. 



The MSMEs indicated that the LGA program is relevant to their needs regarding the training topics, the supporting material and tools, and the connections with the trainers and coaches. Figure 1, shows on a Likert scale from 1 (minimum relevance) to 5 (maximum relevance), that the perceived reliance level by the MSMEs ranges between 4.44 and 4.53, meaning high relevance level. The areas of improvement are discussed in the effectiveness sections below.  
Jobs Creation Validation: The desk review and interviews with the Bloom team revealed that their validation method for the reported jobs is over two steps. At the end of each program cycle, Bloom program managers share a form with the MSMEs that have completed the cycle to understand the impact of the LGA program on the growth of their enterprises. In addition to the basic identification information asked in the form, they invite the MSMEs to share their enterprises’ growth stage, average monthly revenue, jobs created, position type, gender, age, and employee status. After filling out the form, the Bloom team validates the data at two levels. 
The Bloom team addresses the possibility of human error by comparing the total value shared by the enterprise for a specific field concerning the disaggregation count of the value. For example, if the enterprise reports ten full-time jobs created but the disaggregation accounts for nine jobs, they would contact the enterprise to clarify. 
Second, they cross-reference the validated data with the work plan, and budget templates the MSMEs complete during the program implementation to ensure that they meet their targeted employment objectives using the allocated budget. 
For this evaluation, the RPS team ran another data verification method by contacting each MSME to collect the exact number of jobs created, retained, and unfilled jobs, if any. The validation process confirms the retention of 140 jobs created for the Lebanese and 24 for the Refugees. The retention rate of Lebanese workers is 56%, and that of Syrians is 38%. IIII.3 Effectiveness
On the planning Level
One point highlighted and confirmed by both mentors and MSMEs is the divergence in the capacities and needs between the MSMEs in terms of levels and sectors. Hence, their needs differed considerably, which in turn varied their perceptions on the effectiveness of the activities, specifically the training and mentoring sessions. Thus, planning a different training modality (more tailored programs, homogeneous group of MSMEs or mentoring approaches) was recommended during the interviews and focus group discussions with the MSMEs and mentors. Furthermore, the MSMEs, training partners, and mentors agreed the grant phases needed more time.
On the implementation level 
Regarding the implementation of the activities, there is a positive satisfaction from the designed activities. Overall, the level of satisfaction exceeds 68% of the MSMEs. This evaluation shows that the MSMEs need further support in financial management and in securing future funds. The interviews and discussions with the MSMEs and the mentors revealed the gap in the mentoring sessions. Both parties believe that more could be done if the approach for the mentoring sessions was different. While the MSMEs appreciate all the efforts, support, and time provided by the mentors; a more guided, organized, and intensive structure for these sessions would have been more effective. Furthermore, there were repeated comments on matching the mentor (expert) and the MSMEs from both the MSMEs and the mentors. In some cases, the mentors felt helpless as the MSMEs’ needs differed from their area of expertise, so they tried their best to research the information or ask other members in their network to provide plans or answers to the MSMEs. Thus, the need for creating bonding and lineage among LGA mentors was highlighted in the discussion. Instead of referring to their contacts and lose time searching for experts, the mentors could communicate with each other to support each other. Another insight is that the MSME founders felt more knowledgeable than the mentors, and hence little value was added to the process. Therefore, reconsidering the modality of the mentoring sessions could lead to better results. 
Figure 2 LGA Program Activities Rating by the MSMEs

Effectiveness of the Activities
This evaluation confirms the relevance of the activities of the LGA program to the needs of the MSMEs with a variation among the participants about their effectiveness. As for the types of activities designed, there were different views regarding the library, the platform, and the training sessions. However, there was a more unified opinion regarding the mentoring sessions.
The E-library: Some MSMEs and partners valued the information made available on the e-library and relied on it within their exit strategy with the MSMEs. The E-library provides the MSMEs with access to information even after the end of the project. As mentioned by some of the partners “The library and the knowledge available being offered by Bloom is very generous and interesting. The platform and the unified tools and those elements that unify work and produce data and results. It also gives good online networking capabilities. Library was overall rich. The Tools (eCAT) and others were very useful.”   Others did not make much use of it as they perceive it as work in progress and not sure how valid the data shared is and there is also the issue of sharing their own valuable information for free. “We didn’t utilize it much. We know that it has a lot of content, but there is an issue of trust that it is credible and sustainable as a platform.
Plus having to populate this database with valuable content, it needs to be well thought of, developed and paid for.”
The Platform: The platform received high approval from almost all MSMEs participating in this study (74%). This was in terms of commenting, consuming content on the forum or participating in a workshop or discussion. Areas of improvement would include transforming the platform into a more user-friendly navigation system.
Online training Sessions: The online training sessions allowed many MSMEs to benefit from the sessions because they were held remotely, especially during the fuel crisis and inflation crisis. Thus, online training was vital in many MSMEs (84%) attending. One drawback of the online training sessions is the online fatigue that many people experienced in the last phase and the lack of face-to-face interaction that a few mentioned would boost the learning experience.

During the interview, some of the participants (MSMEs) in the evaluation noted that having more customized training sessions tailored to their needs would be more beneficial. For instance, some MSMEs are pretty advanced and do not need pitching sessions but instead need marketing strategies and outreach. Others valued the pitching training sessions and needed more advanced sessions.(Refer to the appendix for the detailed courses distribution from most beneficial to least  per sector and per partner).
 In sector lens analysis, the RPS team divided the MSMEs into seven sectors.  The findings showed that all participating MSMEs benefitted from the capacity building since the rate is over 4 (on a scale from 1 to 5, where 1 is a minimum benefit and 5 is a maximum benefit). Specifically, the MSMEs in the technology and e-commerce, renewables and environmental sector, real estate, and construction sectors were to benefit the most (score 5); next, come the MSMEs in the agriculture, food, and beverages sector (4.33) and the healthcare sector (4.2). Comparatively, the MSMEs in the design, gifting, and education sectors benefitted less than the previously mentioned sectors (4.2 and 4.0, respectively).

The Mentoring Sessions: There is a variation in the responses among the MSMEs and the mentors regarding the mentoring sessions. Among the highlights of the comments is to reconsider the matching criteria between the mentor and the MSMEs. Many mentors feel unable to properly support the MSMEs whose needs do not fit the mentor’s expertise. Similarly, some MSMEs felt more experienced than the mentor and could not benefit appropriately from this activity. 

To a certain extent, the order was reversed compared to the training session input. The MSMEs that benefitted the most (score =5) were in the real estate and construction sector, the health care. Next, those in the renewables and environment (4.33), education (4), and design and gifting (4). The coaching sessions had a lower benefit rate, especially for MSMEs in the agriculture, food, and beverage sector (3.86) and the lowest (3.8) in the technology and e-commerce sector.
The Grant: The grant is significant in supporting the initiatives and it was one of the incentives for many MSMEs to join the LGA program. Moreover, the program helped almost all MSMEs to hire the needed workers they need via the financial support. Only 1 MSME from the participating 39 indicated that the program did not help.

The management Processes 
Overall the MSMEs (90%), the mentors (100%), and the training partners (83%) participating in this assessment, perceive the support and the management process adopted by the Bloom team as very good to excellent. Still, very few considered it fair. The highlights of the responses indicated that the staff was readily available to guide, support, and respond to technical and logistic problems. The only negative impact mentioned was relevant to the delayed grant, and the MSMEs required more clarity

and guidance on this matter. Furthermore, some MSMEs experienced difficulties in obtaining the necessary permits and licenses for the implementation of their projects. Thus, they sought additional support from the Bloom team in navigating the bureaucratic processes.

On another note, most mentors and training partners expressed satisfaction with the LGA program coordination and communication. They appreciated the prompt responses, flexibility, and willingness of the Bloom team to accommodate their needs and support them throughout the project. Nonetheless, some training partners requested improved coordination and harmonization of the training programs to avoid overlaps and redundancies in the content delivered to the MSMEs.

III.4 Efficiency of Project Implementation  
Operating Within a Challenging Economic Situation
Mitigations to External Challenges 
The Bloom team made sure to commit to all the activities under the LGA despite the successive crises (2019 riots, the COVID-19 pandemic, the currency depreciation, electricity outage, Beirut Blast, the banking system default, and the political crisis) that Lebanon is going through. This required an agile, perceptive and adaptive management. Those contextual challenges in Lebanon directly affected Bloom regarding the retention and recruitment of staff, leading to delays in the platform and program. Furthermore, the banking restrictions and the unclear, inconsistent capital controls and measures lead to delays in distributing the grants to the MSMEs.  This by default delayed and affected the flow of the program. 

Mitigations to Internal Challenges
As for the internal challenges faced by the Bloom team, no red flags were mentioned, yet similar to any project, many different parties were involved. A few issues needed to be addressed, such as; the commitment of mentors, retaining the staff, and collecting data from the MSMEs. 
First, the mentors worked voluntarily during the tough economic crisis. Thus, the mentor’s workload is packed, leaving minimal time to engage with voluntary projects. Therefore, the team faced a challenge in securing mentors for the new mentoring sessions. 
Second, there was a turnover in which many staff members moved or travelled seeking better life opportunities, which created further challenges for the remaining Bloom staff to fill the gaps and recruit new members. 
Finally yet importantly, the Bloom team indicated that the relationship with the donor was smooth and supportive in where they worked in partnership mode. On the other hand, the Bloom team had to work timely and follow up with the MSMEs. It was crucial to comply with the reporting requirements and to collect the needed data from them. Keeping in mind their hectic schedules and the economic and financial challenges that they are facing daily to keep their businesses in survival mode. 

Budget Distribution and Costs 
The Bloom team used the budget wisely during the LGA program phases amid the continuously changing economic situation. This included increased financial expenses and the change of practices in Lebanon. 
If we look at “Outcome 1: An effective community of practice (Training Partners and MSMEs) with improved capacities supports MSMEs to operate in complex economic environments”, its total budget was $700,000, which is 34% of the overall project budget. Overall that amount was used to empower and train the local partners. In general, it is reasonable, but considering that there are six partners. The share is relatively low, and programming should be considerably higher in the future to ensure that each partner gets more of the overall budget and scope to give them more ownership and empowerment.
Under “Outcome 2: Capable MSMEs operate successfully complex economic environments,” the total budget was $1,160,000, around 56% of the overall project allocated for capacity building and support to MSMEs. Considering the project's overall budget to be around $2.1 million, with about 564 jobs created, the estimated cost per job completed is $3,700 approximately. But if we calculate the cost of retained jobs, at 164 jobs currently, it would be around $12,700. 

Finally, under “Outcome 3: AltCity Impact / Bloom.org with strengthened organizational abilities to deliver sustained and growing economic impact for MSMEs in complex environments”, a budget of $278,000 was allocated, around 13% of the overall budget. This is a substantial amount considering the scope of the project, in addition to the 7% overhead, which would total 20% of the overall project budget that Bloom utilized for its development and operational growth. 

III.5 Coherence 
Similar Interventions 
While there are several incubators and accelerators in Lebanon and the MENA region, the modality used in the LGA program has its differentiated factors. This is specifically when it comes to access to information via the platform and the E-library aside from the grants and the technical support provided to the MSMEs.

Furthermore, given the deteriorating situation in Lebanon, it is very challenging for any MSME to survive in this environment. Lebanon needs multiple accelerators and incubators throughout the MSMEs journey, whether at the launching phase or for more advanced stages.
Partnerships
The partnership led to mutual benefits for the implementing partners and the Bloom Team. On the one hand, collaboration with implementing partners was necessary to optimize the support to many MSMEs and mitigate the limitations of short staffing and turnover the Bloom team and implementing partners faced. On the other hand, it allowed the implementing partners to benefit from the information, grants, and platform provided shared by the Bloom Team. Hence, the partnership spilled over the impact of the LGA program for a larger pool of MSMEs.
The assessment also showed that an overview of the program was given to the partners, and the same grant ($10,000) per MSME was given, irrespective of which implementing partner is supporting them.
As such, the modality adopted by each implementing partner was slightly different, leading to varying experiences for the MSMEs. However, all MSMEs received the same activities sprint phase, training, mentoring, access to the platform and E-library, and the $10,000 grants. 

III.6 Sustainability  
Sustainability of “Decent Jobs”
Through the empowerment of 49 MSMEs, the LGA program first helped the SME founders to maintain their business and grow them, hence sustaining the jobs of those 49 owners. Second, the program enabled those 49 MSMEs to create 564 jobs in times of crisis. Those created jobs had gender diversity as well as supporting Lebanese and Syrians. The jobs created are of three types: full-time, part-time, and short-term, depending on the capacity and the nature of work for each MSME. For instance, MSMEs in the production sector could hire more full-time employees/workers because they needed more staff. Others of a smaller size or of the services nature relied on part-timers or short-term basis depending on the ability to compensate and the expertise required.  Those who hire full-time workers follow the Lebanese Labor Law regarding the NSSF, work schedule, and other requirements. Those hiring part-time or short-termed workers followed consensual agreements with their employees in light of the market dynamics and rates. 
Up to date, 97% (38 out of 39) of the MSMEs that participated in the evaluation indicated that they are able to retain the Lebanese workers that they hired due to the support of the LGA program and 81% (13 out of 16 MSMEs) were able to retain the Syrian workers hired due to the support of the LGA program.

Part 5: Lessons Learned and Recommendations
Program Level
Jobs Creation
For future programs, a more focused approach on “Job Creation” can be adopted by perhaps engaging medium-sized and established organizations with a solid infrastructure and maybe ten or more staff members to assist them in growing and scale. Moving from this size to grow is usually easier than transitioning from a new initiative, solopreneur, startup, or even a micro-enterprise that is still actively managed by the founder and a few staff members. 
Consider designing the program with a focus on Job Creation through direct MSME support in partial coverage of salaries, organizational capacity development (Policies, Procedures, Manuals, Systems, Licenses, Equipment), operational support (range of legal fees, accounting fees, electricity bills/installation, internet, rent…) and business development support (proposal writing, marketing, sales, pitching to clients, export readiness,…) rather than individual capacity development, coaching, events, and online collaborations.
Refugee Focus 
With the deteriorating situations in Lebanon and compounded crises weighing down more on all residents in Lebanon, there is a natural tendency for MSMEs to worry about the future, not be willing to recruit easily, and when planning to recruit to start with their close circle of friends and relatives. 


Accordingly, refugees are seen in many situations as a competitor to local talent when there is a lot of local talent not finding jobs. Yet, experiences have shown that certain roles and positions are usually easier filled by refugees rather than locals, and a lot of MSMEs would gravitate towards employing refugees in cases where they could not easily find locals to fill positions. The difference is that most expected functions are seasonal, contractual, part-time, or a specific project rather than total or fixed-term employment.  This will eventually reflect in the type of contract, benefits, and remuneration offered. Though pay might be equal to or even higher than counterparts that are getting fixed-term agreements, there is usually no continuity or benefits that come with it.
Moreover, it is important to note that legally employing refugees and registering them with NSSF, Ministry of Labor, and Ministry of Finance is not a straightforward task as the system in Lebanon is still somewhat archaic and thus negatively impacts the compliance of MSMEs in registering the local employees, let along the refugees.
Partnership  (training and localization)
Engaging local partners was one of the success factors of this program, and it is something to build on for the future. One key thing to consider is creating a Steering Committee of the partners that makes decisions at the level of all programs and directs its activities and decisions. This will enable all partners to have a say and more buy-in, enriching the discussions and overall programmatic methodology. 
Moreover, increasing partner budgets is highly recommended to give them leeway to focus on program implementation and their capacity development, sustainability, and growth.
Another possible idea is to consider partners that bring complementary roles, whether research centers, consulting and training firms, digital marketing firms, business development firms, or whatnot. Thus, creating a partnership or a consortium that is not just of partners that can replicate a program but that can play complementary roles whereby each focuses on their key strengths to support the MSMEs and their employees—noting that this approach would considerably change how this program is designed and run but would create an even more impactful program and synergetic partnerships.
Mentors Community 
Mentors are not remunerated; a symbolic stipend would encourage participation. It is encouraged to rethink the mentorship or coaching model from being more of an “add-on” to becoming an integral part of the program whereby each MSME gets a set of coaching/mentoring sessions that they can utilize to help them follow up and grow.
